organic_results.title: Playing the dozens with path analysis: methodological pitfalls in Jencks et al., Inequality
organic_results.snippet: As SOME MAY ALREADY KNOW, black people of all ages frequently play an interpersonal one-upmanship game called" the Dozens." The basic idea of the game is to cleverly insult someone by insulting members of one's family, usually by making derisive comments, preferably of a sexual nature, about one's mother. One ordinarily learns the game during the elementary school years, and often continues to play it on into adulthood. To be good at it, one must possess considerable wit and" street" verbal facility-and also an ability to take it as …
